assoc_actor_1: Students (South Africa); SASCO: South Africa Students Congress
notes: On 14 October 2020, hundreds of SASCO members marched to the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) to hand over a memorandum. Their aim was to highlight poor infrastructure, issues with student funding, outdated curriculums, and problems with student accommodation at the country's Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) colleges. The students tried to force their way into the building after no one came to accept the memorandum. The students also pelted stones at police. Police fired stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.

On 7 October 2020, about 300 trade union members demonstrated in Germiston (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng). No further details reported.
Around 7 October 2020 (week of), a police officer was fatally shot at his home in Bloemspruit in Bloemfontein (Mangaung, Free State). Police have arrested three suspects.

On 7 October 2020, employees of the Johannesburg Property Company stormed a board meeting in Braamfontein (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) demanding changes within the company after allegations against the company relating to nepotism.

On 7 October 2020, a group of community members assaulted and interrogated two men accused of theft in Jabulani, Soweto (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng). One of the men died from his injuries, the other was severely injured.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (South Africa); COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions; NACTU: National Council of Trade Unions; FEDUSA: Federation of Unions of South Africa
notes: On 7 October 2020, about 1000 members of Cosatu, Saftu, Nactu and Fedusa marched to Port Elizabeth City Hall (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) against what they call exploitation of workers by government.
On 7 October 2020, union members demonstrated outside the Dundee hospital (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) ahead of the planned national strike organized by COSATU.

assoc_actor_1: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions; Labor Group (South Africa); DENOSA: Democratic Nursing Organisation of South Africa; Health Workers (South Africa)
source: Highway Mail; News24 (South Africa); Mercury (South Africa); Times (South Africa); IOL
notes: On 7 October 2020, thousands members of COSATU, DENOSA and SAFTU marched in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) against issues around public transport, health and safety, corruption, attacks on collective bargaining, retrenchment and unemployment, gender-based violence and the gender pay gap.

source: IOL; Herald (South Africa); Times (South Africa); Sowetan (South Africa); News24 (South Africa)
notes: On 6 October 2020, about 1500 of farmers gathered in front of the court in Senekal (Thabo Mofutsanyana, Free State) during the hearing of two men accused of killing a farmer. The crowd demanded the suspects to be handed over to them. The demonstrators accused government of not protecting farmers. Two gunshots were fired (not certain by who), a police vehicle was overturned and set alight, and court property were damaged. A number of DA supporters were also part of the demonstration but dispersed when the crowd turned violent. Police arrested one demonstrator.

On 6 October 2020, more than 100 workers from various sectors marched through Johannesburg (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) to hand over a memorandum with a list of demands relating job losses, unemployment and corruption.

assoc_actor_1: CWU: Communication Workers Union; Labor Group (South Africa)
notes: On 6 October 2020, CWU members marched to the department of higher education offices in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), accusing the department of exploiting them. The workers demanded a wage increase.

On 6 October 2020, teachers, pupil and community members demonstrated outside the Western Cape Education Department in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) in support for the principal of the Heathfield High School who is facing a disciplinary hearing for refusing to open the school during the coronavirus peak.
On 6 October 2020, community members barricaded roads with burning rubble in Carletonville (West Rand, Gauteng). The demonstration was over a lack of employment in the area.
On 6 October 2020, parents and pupils demonstrated in Bot River (Overberg, Western Cape) after a scholar transport service by the Western Cape Education Department was suspended.
On 6 October 2020, three armed suspects shot at a bus in Lenasia (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng). A petrol bomb was also hurled at the bus. Several injuries reported. Motive for attack not known.
On 6 October 2020, workers demonstrated outside the Sappi Southern Africa Umkomaas Mill (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), demanding a salary increase.

On 6 October 2020, demonstrators barricaded the M19 near Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) with burning rubble and rocks. Reason for demonstration not reported. Two police officers dispersed the crowd.

source: Pretoria News; Daily Sun (South Africa); EWN; Citizen (South Africa)
notes: On 5 October 2020, members of the Truckers Association of South Africa demonstrated outside the Department of Transport in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding the regulation of the industry with operating licenses and monitoring by the department.

On 5 October 2020, about 100 Early Childhood Development Centre staff and parents demonstrated outside the Social Development Department office in New Brighton (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), pleading with the department for assistance with grants. The workers at the centers have not received salaries during the national coronavirus lockdown.

On 5 October 2020, community members barricaded roads with burning tires in Kleinmond (Overberg, Western Cape) after five men were arrested for abalone poaching. Demonstrators pelted stones at police who used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. A journalist was seriously injured when a brick was smashed through his car window. The demonstrators told journalists that although illegal, the poaching of abalone sustains the community.
On 5 October 2020, demonstrators blocked the N12 near Bedfordview (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) with trucks and motor vehicles. The reason for demonstration not reported.

On 5 October 2020, demonstrators set alight various materials on Seven Passes Road between Knysna (Eden, Western Cape) and George during a demonstration over a delay in housing for them. Law enforcement was on the scene, no mention of intervention.

assoc_actor_1: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa; Labor Group (South Africa)
notes: On 5 October 2020, COSATU and NUMSA members demonstrated outside the Maitland police station (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding the removal of a station commander accused of sexually harassing workers.
On 5 October 2020, more than 200 NSFAS (National Student Financial Aid Scheme) workers demonstrated outside the offices in Wynberg (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding higher salaries.
On 5 October 2020, Gautrain workers demonstrated outside the offices of the Bombela Operating Company in Midrand (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), demanding increased wages.

On 2 October 2020, members of the People's Movement gathered outside the Bloemfontein court (Mangaung, Free State) during the court hearing of seven suspects accused of corruption relating to an asbestos project, calling for the accused to be charged. ANC members also gathered outside the court in support of the accused, calling for senior members of the ANC to be charged.

assoc_actor_1: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League; Labor Group (South Africa)
notes: On 2 October 2020, ANCYL members marched to the Babelegi Industrial Park in Hammanskraal in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding employment.
On 2 October 2020, relatives and community members demonstrated outside the court in Vanderbijlpark (Sedibeng, Gauteng) during the court hearing of a pastor accused of sexual assault.

assoc_actor_1: SDCEA: South Durban Environmental Alliance; ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement; ACM: Active Citizen Movement
notes: On 2 October 2020, about 200 climate activists, including members from SDCEA, ABMSM, and ACM, marched to the Durban City Hall (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), calling for greater action on climate change.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters

Demonstration action were also reported at the Tutuka, Kendal, Lethabo and Majuba power stations. (coded separately).

On 1 October 2020, small business owners demonstrated at the district municipality offices in or near Mount Frere (Alfred Nzo, Eastern Cape), blocking workers from entering. The demonstrators accused the municipality of side lining them for government tenders.

assoc_actor_1: Yoruba Ethnic Group (Nigeria); Biafra Communal Group (Nigeria)
notes: On 1 October 2020, over 100 people from the Yoruba diaspora marched to the British High Commission and the Nigerian embassy in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), calling for the establishment of the Oduduwa Republic. The demonstrators were joined by a dozen of people from the Biafran diaspora, who had their own memorandum, called for similar autonomy for that region.
On 1 October 2020, pupils and parents demonstrated at the Vaal High School in Vanderbijlpark (Sedibeng, Gauteng) following allegations of sexual misconduct at the school.

On 1 October 2020, dozens of residents for several informal settlement communities in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) continued to demonstrate for a second day. Roads were barricaded with guardrails and pelted stones at vehicles, demanding to be relocated.

On 1 October 2020, about 70 elderly people demonstrated outside the William Moffett Expressway in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) after the social development cut subsidies during the national coronavirus lockdown.

On 1 October 2020, Bobani Village residents, near Uitenhage (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), attacked a man suspected of stealing a cell phone and demolished his house. Police intervened and took the man away.
On 1 October 2020, community members marched in Woodlands (uMgungundlovu, KwaZulu-Natal) over the increasing sexual violence happening in the area.
On 1 October 2020, about 100 EFF members marched to the Durban City Hall (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), accusing city officials of corruption.

assoc_actor_1: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
notes: On 1 October 2020, political party supporters, assumed EFF and ANCWL, reportedly scuffled outside the court in Mbombela, formally known as Nelspruit (Ehlanzeni, Mpumalanga) during the court hearing of a MEC and PEC member accused of sexually assaulting two young girls. According to reports, the ANCWL supported the accused while the EFF supported the victims.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (South Africa); NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa

notes: On 30 September 2020, NUMSA members marched to the office of Venture in Rosslyn (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), accusing the managers of hostile action against workers. On 30 September 2020, small business owners barricaded the N2 between Mount Frere (Alfred Nzo, Eastern Cape) and Kokstad with cars and big rocks, accusing the municipality of side lining them for government tenders. Police intervened to reopen the road.

On 30 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing for the third day. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be build in the area. Demonstration action also erupted last week Tuesday and lasted until Friday (coded separately).

On 30 September 2020, Stilwater, Zaailaagte, Schotchill and Scheepersnek community members, including farmers, marched to the AbaQulusi Local Municipality in Vryheid (Zululand, KwaZulu-Natal) to hand over a memorandum that addresses inadequate supply of electricity and water interruptions in the area.

Around 30 September 2020 (week of), Greyton residents demonstrated outside the Theewaterskloof municipal offices in or near Caledon (Overberg, Western Cape) against the sale of an eight hectare piece of land, demanding the land to be used for houses for the community.
On 30 September 2020, taxi drivers blocked roads with their taxis in Seshego (Capricorn, Limpopo) over route disputes.
On 30 September 2020, residents barricaded roads in Philippi (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) with burning rubble. The demonstration was over uncollected garbage for three months.

On 30 September 2020, dozens of residents for several informal settlement communities in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) barricaded roads with burning tires, trees, rubbish and rocks, demanding to be relocated.

On 29 September 2020, Codeta Disadvantaged Taxi Association (DTA) members marched in George (Eden, Western Cape) to hand over a memorandum calling for the association be registered, permits to be given to drivers, and for competition among the taxis and busses to be allowed.

On 29 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing for the second day. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be build in the area. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. Demonstration action also erupted last week Tuesday and lasted until Friday (coded separately).

Around 29 September 2020 (as reported), residents blocked (no mention of physical barriers) the R103 between Colenso (uThukela, KwaZulu-Natal) and Frere in demonstration against a lack of housing and water in the area.

Around 29 September 2020 (as reported), about 40 residents and farm workers demonstrated outside the court in Newcastle (Amajuba, KwaZulu-Natal) during the bail hearing of a man accused of killing a couple on their farm a month ago.
On 29 September 2020, motorists burned tires in front of the license department in Vanderbijlpark (Sedibeng, Gauteng) in frustration over testing center booking dates.

On 29 September 2020, demonstrators barricaded roads with burning tires in Sithembile, Glencoe near Dundee (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) after Eskom workers moved to remove illegal electricity connections in the area.
On 29 September 2020, a large group demonstrated outside the Endumeni Municipality in Dundee (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) to hand over a memorandum. No further information available.

Around 28 September 2020 (as reported), hundreds of rugby fans demonstrated at the Buffalo City Stadium in East London (Buffalo City, Eastern Cape) against the decision to lease the stadium to Chippa United (a soccer club).

On 28 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be build in the area. Demonstration action also erupted last week Tuesday and lasted until Friday (coded separately).
On 28 September 2020, residents of Mdlankomo village demonstrated on the R61 between Mthatha (OR Tambo, Eastern Cape) and Libode, demanding clean water.

Around 28 September 2020 (beginning of week), workers, mostly security guards, general workers and cleaners, demonstrated outside the University of Venda's Univen Innovative Growth Company at Barotta farm in Thohoyandou (Vhembe, Limpopo), demanding salary increase.

Around 28 September 2020 (as reported), the burnt body of a man killed in a suspected mob justice attack was found in Kaulela Street, Nu8, Motherwell (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape). Another body was later recovered from the same street.

On 28 September 2020, family and friends of a woman who was killed by her partner demonstrated outside the court during the bail hearing of the accused in Wynberg (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding bail to be denied.

source: Sowetan (South Africa); Herald (South Africa); Times (South Africa); Daily Sun (South Africa); GardaWorld; SABC News; EWN
notes: On 28 September 2020, community members from various informal settlements including Baby Are You Coming, Anglas Station and Nareng, barricaded roads in Lawley, Lenasia South and Ennerdale (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) with burning tires, rocks and rubble. The demonstration was over the Red Ants planning to demolish their informal housing, reportedly illegally build. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. The demonstrators pelted stones at police.

source: EWN; GardaWorld; Sowetan (South Africa); Daily Sun (South Africa); Times (South Africa); Herald (South Africa); SABC News

The demonstrators pelted stones at police.

On 27 September 2020, a group of environment activists demonstrated in Tokai (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) after the relocation of a baboon. The demonstrators accused the city of not consulting the community and of the mistreatment of all baboons in the city.

Around 26 September 2020 (weekend of), residents of the Kanana informal settlement in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) demolished 18 informal houses belonging to newer residents after they were told that electrification in the area have been delayed due to the new residents.

On 25 September 2020, more than 200 community members, supported by EFF members, demonstrated outside the court in Alexandria (Sarah Baartman, Eastern Cape) during the hearing of a man accused of stabbing a woman who is currently in the hospital, demanding that bail be denied.

On 25 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated for a fourth day over housing. Roads were barricaded with stones and petrol bombs were thrown on the road. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be built in the area.

On 25 September 2020, dozens of climate activists, led by Extinction Rebellion marched to the Port Elizabeth City Hall (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) in solidarity with the Global Climate Strike. A major issue for the demonstrators in Port Elizabeth was its water crisis.

assoc_actor_1: MKMVA: Umkhonto WeSizwe Military Association; Taxi Drivers (South Africa); Labor Group (South Africa); SANTACO: South Africa National Taxi Council
notes: On 25 September 2020, MKMVA members (former ANC military wing), along with the Unemployed Graduates of South Africa and some taxi associations including Santaco, marched to the ANC offices in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) due to frustration of the ANC not addressing corruption, not implementing the 2017 ANC resolutions and not creating job opportunities.

Around 24 September 2020 (as reported), hundreds of community members marched to the municipality in Cradock (Chris Hani, Eastern Cape), demanding that all personnel accused of fraud in the municipality be removed from their positions. A fraud case is currently being investigated by the Hawks, the Directorate for Priority Crime Investigation.

On 24 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated for a third day over housing for the third day. Roads were barricaded with stones and petrol bombs were thrown on the road. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be built in the area.

source: EWN; Citizen (South Africa); African News Agency; Pretoria News; Daily Dispatch; Times (South Africa)
notes: On 23 September 2020, protesters marched to the Nigerian and Zimbabwean embassies in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) to express their concerns over illegal migrants, human trafficking and drug trafficking.

Around 23 September 2020 (as reported), driving school workers demonstrated at the Westonaria Testing Centre (West Rand, Gauteng) demanding that the testing center be opened after it was closed in August due to a break-in.

On 23 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing for the second day. Roads were barricaded with stones and petrol bombs were thrown on the road. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be built in the area.

Around 23 September 2020 (week of), a man was killed by a mob in in Extension 16, Muvhango in Bophelong (Sedibeng, Gauteng) after the mob allegedly caught him stealing from a house. Police found the body surrounded with bricks and sticks.

On 23 September 2020, community members pelted stones at police after they were reportedly evicted from their illegally built housing in Mokopane (Waterberg, Limpopo). Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
On 23 September 2020, residents barricaded roads with burning tires and pelted stones at police vehicles in Hangberg (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) following an anti-land invasion operation.

Around 23 September 2020 (as reported), taxi drivers blocked the corner of Josiah Gumede (Old Main Road) and Anderson Road in Pinetown (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), demanding the release of arrested taxi drivers and the rescinding of traffic violations tickets.

On 22 September 2020, community members scuffled with police at the court in Hammanskraal (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) during the court hearing of a man accused of stabbing a woman to death. The community members demonstrated outside the court but then wanted to gain entrance to the court, police blocked them, leading to a reported shuffle.

On 22 September 2020, demonstrators blocked the N6 between East London (Buffalo City, Eastern Cape) and Newlands. A burning truck was also reportedly blocking the traffic, it was not clear whether the truck was torched by the demonstrators at the time of publishing. Reason for demonstration also not known.

On 22 September 2020, Dipateng and Sione community members blocked (no mention of physical barricades) the roads leading to the N1 near Molemole (Capricorn, Limpopo) for the second day due to water issues in the areas.

On 22 September 2020, taxi drivers blocked roads with their taxis in Parker Street next to the Cleary Park Shopping Centre in Betherlsdorp (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), claiming informal taxis were infringing on their routes. Police were called to the scene to disperse the drivers.

On 22 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing for the third day. Roads were barricaded with stones and petrol bombs were thrown on the road. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be built in the area.

source: Herald (South Africa); Sowetan (South Africa); North Coast Courier; Citizen (South Africa)
notes: On 22 September 2020, community members barricaded the R33 in eBhovini between Pomeroy and Dundee (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) with stones and started to dig up the tar road. The demonstration was over a lack of water and electricity in the area. Three people were arrested.

On 21 September 2020, community members from Phomolomng, Marry Me, Skirlek, Mountain View and several other areas barricaded roads with bricks and burning tires in Mamelodi (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) during a demonstration that started the night before over service delivery issues.

source: Sowetan (South Africa); EWN; News24 (South Africa); Daily Sun (South Africa)
notes: On 21 September 2020, about 60 NEHAWU members demonstrated outside the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding the presidency to address their concerns that relates to compliance by workplaces with the Occupational and Safety Standards Act, centralization of procurement of PPE and implementation of salary agreements during the coronavirus pandemic.
On 21 September 2020, Dipateng and Sione community members blocked (no mention of physical barricades) the roads leading to the N1 near Molemole (Capricorn, Limpopo) due to water issues in the areas.
On 21 September 2020, community members fatally assaulted two men accused of stock theft in Tsolo (OR Tambo, Eastern Cape). No arrests were made.

Around 21 September 2020 (as reported), community members demonstrated to demand justice for some children in Orange Farm (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), demanding the women who were found with a bag containing their clothes to be taken for questioning. There were reportedly chaotic scenes (no mention on what specifically) at the home of children.

On 21 September 2020, community members chased away bulldozers hired by the municipality who were paid to work on a new housing project on vacant land next to the community in Bobani Village in Gunguluza near Uitenhage (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), claiming that the municipality did not consult them.

On 20 September 2020, community members from Phomolomng, Marry Me, Skirlek, Mountain View and several other areas barricaded roads with bricks and burning tires in Mamelodi (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) during a demonstration over service delivery issues.
On 20 September 2020, scores of demonstrators without formal housing marched to the sub-council offices in Khayelitsha (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding basic services.

assoc_actor_2: Red Ant Security Relocation and Eviction Services
source: George Herald (South Africa); Times (South Africa); GroundUp; Sowetan (South Africa)
notes: On 20 September 2020, about a thousand community members looted stores and brought traffic to a standstill in Hornlee near Knysna (Eden, Western Cape) after the Red Ants (private security) demolished their informal housing in Hornlee. During the demolition, the community members pelted stones at the Red Ants. A police officer was injured after police intervened. Four demonstrators were arrested. Police used stun grenades to disperse the crowd.

On 19 September 2020, Better Residents Association (BRA), formerly known as Bushbuckridge Residents Association, members along with EFF members marched to Brooklyn Plantation in Bushbuckridge in Bushbuckridge (Ehlanzeni, Mpumalanga), demanding the resignation of the current president of the party.

On 19 September 2020, a man was fatally assaulted by community members in Constantia Park, Kroonstad (Fezile Dabi, Free State) after the body of a missing girl was found in his house. Police tried to intervene and were also attacked by the mob.
On 19 September 2020, community members held a convoy in Ladysmith (uThukela, KwaZulu-Natal) through the streets, demonstrating against farm murders.

On 19 September 2020, about 50 people, allegedly from Somalia, attacked a car of four suspected Nigerian men accused of kidnapping a child in Parow (City of Cape Town, Western Cape). The group overturned the car, pelted it and attempted to set it alight when police intervened by firing rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.

On 19 September 2020, about 30 demonstrators gathered at the Fairview stables in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) to hold a silent demonstration against the killing of a horse during a violent demonstration by workers on Thursday (coded separately). Police intervened to disperse the demonstrators.

assoc_actor_1: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa; SACCA: South African Cabin Crew Association; Labor Group (South Africa)
notes: On 18 September 2020, South African Airways (SAA) workers, affiliated with NUMSA and SACCA, demonstrated outside the SAA offices in Kempton Park (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) after the government missed the deadline to make funding available for a restructuring plan.
On 18 September 2020, Lilydale community members demonstrated outside the court in Mkhuhlu (Ehlanzeni, Mpumalanga) during the bail hearing of two men accused of killing an elderly woman in Lillydale.

Around 18 September 2020 (as reported), residents from Zwide burned tires after waiting for hours for water tankers in Missionvale (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) after communities in Ibhayi, Govan Mbeki, Veeplaas, Soweto on Sea, New Brighton, KwaZakhele, Zwide and Missionvale were left without water. The water tankers ran out of water, causing frustration.

assoc_actor_1: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Health Workers (South Africa)
notes: On 18 September 2020, health workers, supported by the EFF, marched to the municipal offices in Vereeniging (Sedibeng, Gauteng), demanding their three-month backdated salaries.

On 18 September 2020, the Ahmed Kathrada Foundation and civil society organizations demonstrated at Constitutional Hill in Braamfontein (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) against corruption. The demonstration was over coronavirus relief funds that were stolen and mismanaged.

On 18 September 2020, an off duty police officer from the Anti-Gang Unit (AGU) was gunned down at his home in Bishop Lavis (City of Cape Town, Western Cape). One arrest made, reportedly a former rugby player. More arrests were not ruled out as investigations were still under way.
On 18 September 2020, about 50 people demonstrated in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), demanding the arrest of people accused of looting the coronavirus fund that was started in March.
On 18 September 2020, community members fatally assaulted a man accused of robbery in Tongaat (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal).
On 17 September 2020, a group of 80 youth demonstrated at the newly renovated Motherwell Shopping Centre (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), demanding new shops to employ local youths.

On 17 September 2020, demonstrators barricaded roads with branches and burning tires and set alight a car in Dinokana Village, near Zeerust (Ngaka Modiri Molema, North-West). Police were on the scene to intervened. The demonstrators pelted stones at police. The demonstration was over water issues in the area.
On 17 September 2020, community members in Laingville (West Coast, Western Cape) demonstrated over land issues.

On 17 September 2020, demonstration action was reported outside the Murraysburg court (Central Karoo, Western Cape) during the court hearing of two men accused of assaulting a man looking for farm work. The group reportedly gathered in support of the accused.

Around 17 September 2020 (as reported), community members assaulted and almost set alight a teen accused of attempting to rape a young girl in Alexandra (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng). The accused was taken to hospital.
On 17 September 2020, an off-duty police officer was fatally shot inside his car by unknown armed gunmen in Khayelitsha (City of Cape Town, Western Cape).

On 17 September 2020, scores of people, mostly women, demonstrated outside the court in Roodepoort (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) during the bail hearing of two men accused of raping two women and killing the one, demanding bail to be denied.

assoc_actor_1: Christian Group (South Africa); Labor Group (South Africa)
notes: Around 17 September 2020 (as reported), civil society, churches, unions and business owners demonstrated outside the City Hall in Nelson Mandela Bay also known as Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) to demonstrate against the administration of the municipality.

source: Daily Sun (South Africa); SABC News; EWN; IOL; Polokwane Review
notes: On 17 September 2020, a soldier shot and injured a man in Mogwadi, formerly called Dendron, (Capricorn, Limpopo) for not wearing a face mask during the national coronavirus lockdown. According to some reports, the man attempted to take the soldier's firearm during a scuffle. The soldier has been arrested.

source: Daily Sun (South Africa); Citizen (South Africa); Carletonville Herald; EWN; Diamond Fields Advertiser
notes: On 17 September 2020, between 150 and 200 former workers of the Fairview stables in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), stormed the stables, set 28 horses free and stabbed and killed a horse, demanding their UIF payments.

assoc_actor_1: TUMSA: Trade Union of Musicians of South Africa; Labor Group (South Africa)
notes: On 16 September 2020, about 50 artists, supported by TUMSA, marched to Parliament in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding for the immediate provisional opening of performance venues up to 70 per cent capacity during the coronavirus lockdown, an allocation of R600 million to the arts sector and an inter-ministerial task group to be set up to review, propose and implement revised strategies to grow the sector.

On 16 September 2020, a group of artists marched to the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng). The group accused government of being impractical on the criteria for the coronavirus relief fund.

On 16 September 2020, about 100 undertakers blocked the N2 in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) with coffins as they marched to the department of Home Affairs, demanding that the industry be regulated and that by-laws be amended by municipalities to enable cluster storage.

On 16 September 2020, demonstration action was reported in Dinokana Village, near Zeerust (Ngaka Modiri Molema, North-West) over water-related issues. Police allegedly fired rubber bullets at the house of an elderly woman, breaking the windows of the house and accusing her of encouraging the youth to protest. It is assumed police also used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.

On 16 September 2020, about 50 Samora Machel and Kosovo residents, supported by EFF members, marched to the Philippi police station (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) demanding the arrest of a man accused of killing his partner, for protection and visibility of police officers in the area, regular updates on the case from the detective, and the immediate transfer of the case from the local police station to the province with regular updates.
On 16 September 2020, community members set alight a house in Siloam near Makhado (Vhembe, Limpopo) when they were searching for a man accused of murder.
On 15 September 2020, church leaders held a silent demonstration at the St George's Cathedral in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) against corruption.

On 15 September 2020, about 50 residents demonstrated at Parliament in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), claiming the city failed to respond to their calls for assistance with an overflowing sewage canal.
On 15 September 2020, church leaders held a silent demonstration at the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) against corruption.

On 15 September 2020, Tokyo informal settlement residents barricaded roads with burning tires and three vehicles were set alight in Germiston (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) over service delivery issues in the area. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.

On 15 September 2020, parents of pupils in Inkqubela Primary School demonstrated outside the school in Kwazakhele (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), demanding fencing around the school that had been vandalized.

Around 15 September 2020 (as reported), a handful of Winnies Park community members, mostly women, marched to the Boipatong Police Station in Vanderbijlpark (Sedibeng, Gauteng), demanding the recognition and awareness of the BMW patrollers (a community-led patrolling group). This followed a series of stories that were published by Sedibeng Ster about a group of patrollers that has apparently become a law unto themselves in Boipatong.

On 15 September 2020, masses demonstrated outside the court in Polokwane (Capricorn, Limpopo) during the case hearing of two men accused of killing a restaurant owner and her mother, calling for justice to take its course.

On 15 September 2020, hundreds of taxi drivers barricaded the Mew Way bridge in Khayelitsha (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) during a taxi route dispute between Congress for Democratic Taxi Association and the Cape Amalgamated Taxi Association.

On 15 September 2020, two men, in Nanduwa patrol cars (Taxi association patrol vehicles), were fatally shot by three armed men near Nancefield Hostel in Soweto (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng). The incident is suspected to be related to taxi violence.

On 15 September 2020, about 100 students from TVET colleges and Nelson Mandela University marched to the Port Elizabeth City Hall (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) to hand over a memorandum, The students are demanding that the municipality fulfil a previous commitment to convert derelict buildings in the metro into student accommodation at low rentals.

source: Daily Dispatch; Times (South Africa); North Coast Courier
notes: On 15 September 2020, about 200 community members barricaded road in Pomeroy (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) with burning tires and stones and damaged some infrastructure in a demonstration over a lack of water in the area. Police were on the scene (no mention of intervention).
On 14 September 2020, community members demonstrated outside the court in Moretele (Bojanala Platinum, North-West) during the court hearing of a man accused of murder.
On 14 September 2020, unemployed youth barricaded roads leading to Impala Platinum mine in Rustenburg (Bojanala Platinum, North-West) with burning tires and rocks, demanding employment at the mine.

On 14 September 2020, about 30 farmers demonstrated at the court in Ventersdorp (Dr Kenneth Kaunda, North-West) during the bail hearing of six men accused of shooting and injuring a farmer during a farm attack in Klerkskraal, demanding bail to be denied.
On 14 September 2020, a demonstration over land issues was reported in Bathurst (Cacadu, Eastern Cape).

On 14 September 2020, undertakers demonstrated outside the Chris Hani Baragwanath Academic Hospital in Soweto (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), demanding that the industry be regulated and that by-laws be amended by municipalities to enable cluster storage.

On 14 September 2020, EFF members demonstrated outside the court in Randburg (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) during the case hearing of the EFF leader and a MP accused of assaulting a police officer in 2018 (coded separately) in Soweto during the state funeral of a political activist.

Around 14 September 2020 (as reported), residents demonstrated at the Thornton Road Primary School in Crawford (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) against the planned building of a cell tower on the school grounds. The demonstrators said they have not been consulted about the cell tower.

On 14 September 2020, Cape Flats Women's Network members demonstrated outside the Wynberg court (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) during the bail hearing of two men accused of raping a teen, demanding bail to be denied.

On 13 September 2020, about 25 zama-zamas (unlawful miners) shot at a security guard in Carletonville (West Rand, Gauteng). The security guard survived the attack.

On 11 September 2020, 15 artists marched to the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) to hand over a memorandum. The memorandum related to coronavirus relief funds not received and the closure of all entertainment facilities during the lockdown.

On 11 September 2020, about 40 people from Thembisile Hani, Dr JS Moroka, and Elias Motsoaledi municipalities demonstrated at the Union Building in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding a rail corridor to be built.
On 11 September 2020, EFF members demonstrated outside the BMW dealership in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) after an advertisement was posted for a vacancy for a white man or woman.

On 11 September 2020, taxi association demonstrations were reported in Polokwane (Capricorn, Limpopo). Taxis blocked Grobler Street for hours. A group pelted stones at a taxi in Buite street. A taxi driver (assumed from an opposed taxi association) fires shots at the group, injuring one.

source: GroundUp; Pretoria News; News24 (South Africa); Daily Sun (South Africa)
notes: On 11 September 2020, about 40 Mpumalanga residents demonstrated at the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding progress on the proposed Moloto Road and rail corridor.

On 11 September 2020, a church group and the Salvation Army marched to the Vryheid police station (Zululand, KwaZulu-Natal) to deliver a memorandum on gender-based violence.
Around 11 September 2020 (as reported), residents from Malabar (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) demonstrated over the closure of the local clinic due to gang related incidents.

On 11 September 2020, hundreds of community members demonstrated at the Ocean Basket (restaurant) in Mall of the North in Polokwane (Capricorn, Limpopo) after a restaurant owner and her mother was murdered the day before.

Police used stun grenades to disperse the crowd. Four demonstrators were arrested.

On 10 September 2020, three Lesotho nationals were killed with knobkieries (a fighting stick, usually with a knob on the end). Their bodies were found on a farm in Fouriesburg (Lejweleputswa, Free State). According to some eye witnesses, the victims had earlier that morning been seen with three police officers, allegedly from Lesotho who were following information about stock theft that occurred in Lesotho.

notes: On 10 September 2020, a scuffle broke out between EFF members and security guards in Norkem Mall in Kempton Park (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng). EFF members demonstrated in front of the Clicks store against an advertisement posted by the store and TRESemme depicting black women's hair as frizzy, dull and damaged, comparing it with images of white women's hair which was described as was fine, flat and normal. The group called for the end of racism and for the naming of the person who approved the advertisement and for all TRESemme products to be recalled for 10 days. One of the EFF members was allegedly assaulted by security guards.
